Takes him out to look at the Queen
 Only place that he’s ever been
 Always shouts out something obscene

In The Beatles: The Biography, Bob Spitz reported Lennon had said he was planning on saying “…rattle your f – ing jewellery” while delivering his now infamous (clean) quip at the Royal Command Performance.Seemingly this story finds its way into Mean Mr Mustard, however, who’s taken out to look at the queen and always shouts out something obscene.
Shaves in the dark trying to save paper

The utility power to light a bathroom costs money. Shaving in the dark saves paper (slang for money).
It’s quite possible John struck a second, less obvious meaning illustrating how eccentric, and quite backwards, Mr. Mustard obviously is as anyone who is shaving in the dark with the intent of saving paper, that being toilet paper in this meaning, is going to fail, they’re going slice their face up necessitating the use of the toilet paper (as well as the money paper) they were intending to save in the first place

Such a mean old man
 Such a mean old man

Lennon may have pulled some inspiration from the play Look Back in Anger.

In a conversation between characters Cliff and Jimmy, Cliff asks to borrow Jimmy’s copy of News of the World. Jimmy refuses, angrily telling Cliff that he will need to pay for the news. Cliff retorts by calling Jimmy a “mean old man.”

News of the World is referenced in the following track, “Polythene Pam,” and there is proof that Lennon was — at the very least — aware of Look Back in Anger.
She never stops, she’s a go-getter
What they mean by “go-getter”, is someone that works hard and never stops to gain something that they desire. (Money)
His sister Pam works in a shop
This part was added in (John’s original lyric had her name as Shirley) to fit with the medley concept. So yeah, Mr. Mustard and Polythene Pam are siblings.
Keeps a ten-bob note up his nose

Ten Bob Note = 10 shilling note. This is a note from before Britain decimalised its currency, and was equivalent to half an old pound.

Although the image of a money up someone’s nose is reminiscent of the common practice of snorting cocaine through a rolled up bill, John Lennon has stated in a 1980 interview that it had nothing at all to do with the drug. He said he read a newspaper story about a miser who concealed his cash not in his nose, but apparently in his anus in order to prevent people from forcing him to spend it. However, “asshole” wouldn’t be exactly fitting for a mainstream song in the late 1960s so it was changed.

John 1980:

I’d read somewhere in the newspaper about this mean guy who hid his five-pound notes, not up his nose but “somewhere else.” No, it had nothing to do with cocaine.

Paul circa-1994:

“Mean Mr Mustard” was very John. I liked that. A nice quirky song.

Lennon wrote the song while he was in India with the other Beatles, after he read a newspaper story about a miser who concealed his cash wherever he could in order to prevent people from forcing him to spend it.
